author: Anonymous Gear
title: Termination Arguments: Reduction Step
question:
In this review of the termination arguments video, it seems to me that the reduction step would be (scarpet (/ s 3)), because without the function call, (/ s 3) itself doesn't factor into the recursion.
I'm honestly not sure if the distinction matters, but in case it does, here's my chance to learn about it.
student_answer: You're correct in saying that  (scarpet (/ s 3)) would be the recursion. What the reduction step is is simply how does the parameter ('s') change with each recursion.
instructor_answer:
By reduction step we mean how is the data reduced in the recursive call. So (scarpet (/ s 3)) is the recursive call and (/ s 3) is the reduction step. 

It’s called reduction because it is supposed to reduce the complexity of the data by getting it one step closer to the trivial case.
